title: imputetoolkit
text: Handling missing data remains one crucial tasks applied data science. Whether caused sensor failures, survey non-responses, data-entry mistakes, missingness can bias analyses reduce model performance. Simple techniques like listwise deletion often waste data. principled strategies use imputation replacing missing values reasonable estimates. However, single method performs best data types distributions. imputetoolkit package provides R + C++ unified framework inject, impute, evaluate, visualize different imputation strategies side side.

title: imputetoolkit
text: imputetoolkit performs full imputation benchmarking pipeline: Controlled missingness injection Multi-method imputation: Mean / Mode (skewness-aware log transform) Median / Mode MICE KNN (parallel mixed-type imputation using FNN) Split evaluation numeric categorical features via C++ back-end Metric computation using Rcpp efficiency Automatic best-method suggestions Visual comparisons (metrics + density plots)

title: imputetoolkit
text: main entry point evaluator() function: Internally, function: Loads dataset uses provided data frame. Detects numeric vs categorical columns. Injects missing values controlled proportions. Performs four imputation methods (Mean/Mode, Median/Mode, MICE, KNN). Evaluates using: Numeric metrics: RMSE, MAE, R², Correlation, KS. Categorical metrics: Accuracy, Kappa, F1, Macro F1, Balanced Accuracy. Returns named list "evaluator" objects, one per method.

title: imputetoolkit
code: # Load the built-in mixed-type dataset file <- system.file("extdata", "synthetic_mixed_dataset.csv", package = "imputetoolkit") raw_data <- read.csv(file, stringsAsFactors = TRUE)  # Run the full evaluator pipeline res <- evaluator(data = raw_data)

what: Example 2 - Split Evaluation: Numeric vs Categorical
title: imputetoolkit
text: imputation result now contains two separate metric groups: Example numeric-metric output (truncated): Example categorical-metric output:
code: names(res$mean_mode) #> [1] "method" "metrics_numeric" "metrics_categorical" --- Numeric Metrics ---    RMSE    MAE      R2  Correlation    KS   0.2068  0.1750  -0.0001   0.0000   0.5068 --- Categorical Metrics ---   Accuracy  Kappa   F1  MacroF1  BalancedAccuracy    0.2782   0.0000  0.2782  0.1295  0.2700

what: Example 3 - Suggesting the Best Imputation Method
title: imputetoolkit
text: Typical output:
code: # Single-metric suggestion suggest_best_method(res, "RMSE")  # Aggregate suggestion across all metrics suggest_best_method(res, "ALL") Numeric Columns:    Best imputation method as per "RMSE, MAE, R2, KS" metric: Mean/Mode    Best imputation method as per "Correlation" metric: MICE  Categorical Columns:    Best imputation method as per "Kappa" metric: KNN    Best imputation method as per "Accuracy, F1, BalancedAccuracy" metric: Mean/Mode    Best imputation method as per "MacroF1" metric: MICE

title: imputetoolkit
text: following visualizations summarize compare imputation performance across methods.

title: imputetoolkit
text: Figure 1. Comparison four imputation methods - KNN, Mean/Mode, Median/Mode, MICE, across numeric categorical evaluation metrics. facet represents specific metric, x-axis showing imputation methods side side. plot enables quick visual comparison helps identify method performs best overall.
code: plot_metrics(res, metric = "RMSE")            # Numeric plot_metrics(res, metric = "Accuracy")        # Categorical plot_metrics(res, metric = "ALL")

what: Example 5 - Distributional Similarity via Density Plots
title: imputetoolkit
text: Distribution plots help verify whether imputed values preserve shape original data. Distribution overlap true imputed values can visualized:  Figure 2. True (blue) imputed (red) value distributions across numeric variables imputation methods. column represents method row variable. Greater overlap blue red curves indicates closer preservation original data distribution.
code: eval_list <- get_eval_list(res)  # Single column plot_density_per_column(eval_list, "age") plot_density_all(eval_list)

text: wrapper prints summary tables, draws metric plots, automatically reports top-performing imputation methods.

title: imputetoolkit
text: evaluate_imputation_split() computes numeric categorical metrics C++ speed. Numeric metrics → RMSE, MAE, R², Correlation, KS Categorical metrics → Accuracy, Kappa, F1, Macro F1, Balanced Accuracy

title: imputetoolkit
text: imputetoolkit now supports split numeric/categorical evaluation automated visualization within one reproducible workflow. Unified interface multiple imputation strategies Rcpp-accelerated metric computation Parallel KNN mixed-type data Density & metric visualizations Best-method recommendations metric type Ideal research, teaching, benchmarking imputation methods.

title: Imputation Toolkit for Evaluating Missing Data Methods
text: imputetoolkit R package evaluating benchmarking missing-data imputation techniques using unified R + C++ backend. automates full workflow data preparation → missingness injection → imputation → metric-based evaluation → visualization, providing numeric categorical assessments. parallel computation, C++ acceleration, intuitive S3 interface (print, summary, plot), package allows users quantitatively justify imputation strategy choices.

title: Imputation Toolkit for Evaluating Missing Data Methods
code: imputetoolkit/ ├── DESCRIPTION ├── NAMESPACE ├── R/ │   ├── evaluator.R             # main pipeline + S3 interface │   ├── plot_metrics.R          # plotting utilities │   ├── print_summary.R         # print() & summary() methods │   ├── utils.R                 # helper utilities │   └── RcppExports.R           # glue between R and C++ ├── src/ │   ├── evaluate_imputation_split.cpp   # C++ backend for numeric + categorical metrics │   ├── RcppExports.cpp │   └── (future extensions) ├── inst/extdata/               # sample datasets ├── vignettes/                  # user guide (html_vignette) └── tests/testthat/             # full unit test suite

title: Imputation Toolkit for Evaluating Missing Data Methods
text: Main pipeline executes: 1. Data loading input validation 2. Missingness injection 3. Imputation via four methods 4. Metric evaluation (numeric & categorical) 5. Return structured evaluator objects Returns: object contains:

title: Imputation Toolkit for Evaluating Missing Data Methods
text: print.evaluator() – concise summary metric type summary.evaluator() – per-column aggregated results print_metrics() – combined table across methods plot_metrics() – ggplot visualization metric suggest_best_method() – identifies top-performing methods evaluate_results() – runs print + plot + recommendation get_eval_list() – extracts true/imputed pairs density plots plot_density_per_column() / plot_density_all() – visualize true vs imputed distributions

Imputation Toolkit for Evaluating Missing Data Methods
text: Split-metric evaluation: numeric categorical metrics handled separately. C++ acceleration: high-performance evaluation safe NA handling. Parallel KNN: multi-core computation mixed-type datasets. Skewness-aware mean imputation: applies log + geometric mean |skewness| > 1. Reproducible pipeline: consistent metrics across runs (set.seed() used). Custom plotting: side--side bar charts, density overlays, panel comparisons.

title: Imputation Toolkit for Evaluating Missing Data Methods
text: Function references: ?evaluator, ?plot_metrics, ?suggest_best_method Vignette tutorial: vignette("imputetoolkit") Online docs: pkgdown site

title: Imputation Toolkit for Evaluating Missing Data Methods
text: Modular design: easy extension new imputation algorithms (e.g. missForest, EM). Full testthat coverage >50 passing tests. Fully vectorized Rcpp implementation. Works seamlessly knitr / rmarkdown reproducible reports.
